properties.title: Mr. P.'s Farm
properties.note: Latrobes Party reached the last point on their travel into the cape colony at the Farm of a Mr. P. The landdrost asked them to have a look at the place, which they did. After examining the farm and talking to the farmer himselfe they decided, to having been traveled far enough and therefore not to proceed any further. Also all other places further to be investigated and proposed by the landdrost of Uitenhagen where either occupied or in Caffraria (Xhosa-Land) and therefore not inhabitable with Khoikhoi-Settlements. This last farm is only described as an hour away from Somerset Farm, following the mountain range and fording the Small Fish River twice. Therefore the position is more of an estimation.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 231
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/230/mode/2up

properties.title: Mr. Van Klerk's farm
properties.note: Latrobe and his fellows visited this farm after ending their exploration to the east. The farm is marked at Latrobes map as laying south of the union of Small Fish River and Brake River, which seem to not exist anymore today. An exact position is not givin, therefore the markers position is more of an estimation based on multiple historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 234
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/234/mode/2up

properties.title: Mr. Engelbrecht's Farm
properties.note: Latrobe's party reached the farm of a Mr. Engelbrecht on their way back towards the Suurberg mountain range. Latrobe himself does not further describe the place, but it is marked on the historical map attached to his journal. The position was estimated using this map and comparing it to a recent map. Another indicator to the position is the nearby summit called Engelbrecht se Kop, but still the actual location is rather a vague estimation.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 236
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/236/mode/2up

properties.title: Zuurberg
properties.note: The travellers passed the Zuurberg on the same way they used on their outbound route. The Position is still an estimation since there are multiple passes over the mountain range.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 237
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/236/mode/2up

properties.title: Ado's Drift on Zondag's Revier
properties.note: Latrobe's party splits in two groupes. While Brother Stein and Sister Schmitt took the Khoikhoi to the Witte Revier Valley for them to have a look at the place, Latrobe proceedes further acoompanied by Mr. Melville and the Khoikhoi Leonhard Paerl and Johannes. They set out to Uitenhagen and halt at Ado's Drift on Zondags Revier. The exact position is hardly to estimate, but until today their remains a small settlement called Addo on Sondagsrivier or Sundays River, that might be named after that place. The position is therefore an optimisitc estimation.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 239
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/238/mode/2up

properties.title: Uitenhagen
properties.note: Latrobe and his fellows reached the settlement and its drosty on their outbound as well as on their return route. They met the landdrost Colonel Cuyler, who helped them with their furtehr journey, Mr. Allen, the secretary of the Governer at Cape Town and a german Gentleman Mr. Von Buchenrode who supported the groupe by providing meals and supplies on both visits. The former Drosty still exists and houses the Drosty Museum of Uitenhage or Kariega, as the city is called today. (Descriptions of the retourn bound are found on page 239)
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 203
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/202/mode/2up

properties.title: Van Stadensrivier
properties.note: Latrobes travel groupe passes the Van Stadens River on their return route to Kaffre Kraal and Klaarefonteyn, the farms of the Brothers Neukirch. Since the farms did not remain and the exact point of crossing the river is not mentioned, the position of the marker is an estimation.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 241
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/241/mode/2up

properties.title: Chamtoos Wagedrift on Klein Revier
properties.note: Latrobe and his fellow Mr. Melville reached this location after the rest of the travellers, because they made an extra halt at a farm of a Mr. Van Roy on the banks of the Lorie River or Loeriespruit, as it is called today. Since the farm is not marked, this is the next point that can be estimated upon the historical map attached to the journal.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 243
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/242/mode/2up

properties.title: Klein Revier Farm
properties.note: While passing the Chamtoose Revier Wagendrift, Latrobe, Brother Schmitt and the Khoikhoi Marcus made a short detour to a farm on Klein Revier recommended to them as a possibly fitting place for a new mission by the landdrost of Uitenhagen. Latrobe therefore feels the urge to at least have a look at it, although he describes that there is already a farmer applying for the land. He describes the position as 2 to 3 english miles up the river. Based on this description, the position of the former farm was estimated.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 244
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/244/mode/2up

properties.title: Chamtoos Wagedrift on Klein Revier
properties.note: Latrobe and his fellow Mr. Melville reached this location after the rest of the travellers, because they made an extra halt at a farm of a Mr. Van Roy on the banks of the Lorie River or Loeriespruit, as it is called today. Since the farm is not marked, this is the next point that can be estimated upon the historical map attached to the journal.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 243
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/242/mode/2up

properties.title: Ausflucht
properties.note: Latrobe visits this farm after passing the Gamtoose River. The place is estimated upon the historical map attached to the journal. Main tether is the union of the rivers Wagebooms and Chamtoos marked in the map. Today the rivers a very likely the Gamtoose River and the Kouga River.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 245
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/244/mode/2up

properties.title: Essenbosch
properties.note: Latrobe and his compagnions passed the Essenbosch farm as they did on their outbound route. They stayed only a few hours before proceeding. The position is estimated upon historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 246
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/246/mode/2up

properties.title: Jagersbosch
properties.note: Latrobe and his fellows visited the Jagersbosch Farm of Mr. Akkerman as they did on their outbound. They stayed a night, purchased new oxen and proceeded along the Kromm River as before. The position is an estimation made upon historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 247
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/246/mode/2up

properties.title: Mr. Mey's Farm
properties.note: The travellers halted at the farmland belonging to Mr. Mey, both on their outbound and return routes. On their outbound here the party splitted to visit Mr. Mey and the farm Ellandsfonteyn in the close surrounding to get new oxen to proceed further. On the return they tried the same but could not get any new oxen. Comparing Latrobes map and a historical map of the same year, it shows that the farm has been called Miegunst. A small settlement of nearly the same name (Misgund) remains until today.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 185 (Description of the return route on Page 247 f.)
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/184/mode/2up

properties.title: Ellandsfonteyn
properties.note: Latrobe and his fellows visited Mr. Piet Fereira's farm Ellandsfonteyn on their return route again. Today there are no remains of the farm, therefore the position was estimated upon historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 248
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/248/mode/2up

properties.title: Kliphübel
properties.note: The Travellers visited the former farm of the veldcornet Stephen Fereira again on their return route. The exact place of the Farm can only be roughly estimated using historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 249
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/248/mode/2up

properties.title: Wellgelegen
properties.note: The Travellers breefly haltet at the former farm for some tea and supplies before continuing their return journey. The exact place of the farm can only be roughly estimated using historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 252
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/252/mode/2up

properties.title: Mr. Zondag's farm at Avantur
properties.note: Latrobe and his fellows were warmly welcomed and treated with greatest hospitality, as Latrobe describes it. The settlement today called Avontuur still exists, as well as a property belonging to a family called Zondagh, that might be related to Mr. Zondag.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 253
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/252/mode/2up

properties.title: Gaensekraal
properties.note: Latrobe and the fellow travellers spend a night on the farm Gaensekraal of the veldcornet Michael Rendsberg, where they were welcomed very hospitally. Although the farm did not remain until today, the position was estimated upon historical maps and a small stream called Gansekraalrivier or Gansrivier still existing today.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 254
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/254/mode/2up

properties.title: Eseljagd River
properties.note: Latrobe and his travelling compagnions haltet at the banks of the Eseljagd or Zebra Hunt River (today called Eseljagdrivier).The position of their halt was estimated upon historical maps and assumptions about the most likely route.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 255
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/254/mode/2up

properties.title: Great Dorn River
properties.note: The travel party passes several waypoints described in a way that suggests that they were mooving northward of George from east to west, passing several kloofs, likely parallel to the Olifants River, which was visible from time to time. Since nearly all waypoints were farms that do not exist anymore, the next position, that can be estimated is the Great Dorn River or Groot-Doringrivier as it is called today.The position of their fording point was estimated roughly.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 256
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/256/mode/2up

properties.title: Groote Paerdekraal
properties.note: This farm of a Mr. Rutter was situated in the mountaisn towards the Attaquas Kloof, which today is likely called the Attakwaskloof Nature Reserve. Latrobe and his fellows stayed their on their return route. There is little to no way to mark the exact position of the former farm. A cautious estimation was made using the historical attached to his Journal, a historical map of 1815 and recent maps. Still this point is one of the most vague estimations made mostly to ensure some kind of trace of the travellers way.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 259
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/258/mode/2up

properties.title: Attaquas Kloof
properties.note: The group around Latrobe is moving through the Attaquas Kloof or Attakwaskloof Pass as it is called today. The pass is more of a tableland which takes several days to cross. Latrobe visits a farm called Haagekraal in this area. Unfortunately no remaining data refernig to this farm was found, therefore the position is kept vaguely.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 261
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/260/mode/2up

properties.title: Hunykliff Kloof
properties.note: Latrobe and his fellows reached a farm called Hunykliff Kloof belonging to a german called Mr. Krieg, after passing the Attakwaskloof. Although the farm is not remaining, the position was estimated upon the historical map attached to the Journal.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 262
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/262/mode/2up

properties.title: Gowritz River
properties.note: Latrobes groupe passes the Gowritz River or Gouritsrivier after visiting Hunykliff Kloof. The exact position is not described, therefore the marker is set to an estimated point of crossing the river.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 262
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/262/mode/2up

properties.title: Duivenhoeks Revier
properties.note: Latrobes groupe moved westwards from the Gowritz River towards the Duivenhoeks Revier or Duiwenhoksrivier passing several farms that did not remain until today. Therefore an exact position, where the travellers forded the river can only be vaguely estimated upon historical maps, manly the map attached to the journal.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 265
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/264/mode/2up

properties.title: Bueffeljagd's Revier
properties.note: The travellers turned to Mr. Buissini's farm on Bueffeljagd' revier or Buffeljagsrivier, as it is called today. Since there are no remains of the former farm, the postion was estimated using historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 266
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/266/mode/2up

properties.title: Zwellendam
properties.note: After fording the Buffeljagsrivier at lower water level, the travellers reached Zwellendam (Swellendam) at noon, where they stayed at the drosty again. They than took some tours at the settlement, visiting important persons and buildings.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 267
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/266/mode/2up

properties.title: Breede River
properties.note: The travellers forded the Breede River in the forenoon, having some trouble, because it started raining and not only the water level started rising, but the way to the banks of the river became slippery. Using a Ferry for their waggons and letting the oxen swim freely, they managed to cross the Breede River again. Since no exact place of said ferry is mentioned, the location is an estimation based upon the historical map attached to the journal.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 268
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/268/mode/2up

properties.title: Mr. Van Helsland's Farm
properties.note: The travellers forded the Breede River in the forenoon, having some trouble, because it started raining and not only the water level started rising, but the way to the banks of the river became slippery. Using a Ferry for their waggons and letting the oxen swim freely, they managed to cross the Breede River again. Since no exact place of said ferry is mentioned, the location is an estimation based upon the historical map attached to the journal.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 268
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/268/mode/2up

properties.title: Hartebeestkraal
properties.note: Last halt before reaching the end of Latrobes journey to the east was a farm called Hartebeestkraal. Its exact position is not givin, theirfore an estimation based on the travle route and a mountain called Hartebeest in the nearby was made. This marker therefore stayes rather vague.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 268
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/268/mode/2up

properties.title: Gnadenthal
properties.note: Endingpoint of C. I. Latrobes easternmost excursion throughout the Cape Colony of 1816 nearly to the borders of former so called Kaffraria. Latrobe returned 1 Month and 6 Days later.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 270
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/270/mode/2up
